title: Day 1259

# Day 1259

Once upon a time there was a wealthy businessman who spent his entire life accumulating riches. Gold, silver, precious gems, real estate, stock portfolios worth millions, you name it. When he died, he found himself at the gates of heaven, clutching desperately at the idea of leaving everything behind.

"Please," he begged the angel at the gate, "I've worked so hard for all of this. Surely I can bring something with me?"

"I'm sorry," the angel replied, "but nothing material can cross over. Those are the rules."

The man pleaded and bargained for what felt like eternity until finally the angel, moved by his distress, made an unprecedented exception: "Alright, one suitcase. That's all. Make sure you choose wisely."

Overjoyed, the man rushed back to earth and carefully selected the most concentrated wealth he could carry - pure gold bars, filling every inch of the suitcase. He returned to heaven's gates triumphant.

As he passed through, other angels gathered curiously around his suitcase. "What on earth did you bring?" they asked.

He opened it proudly, revealing the gleaming gold. The angels looked puzzled and began to chuckle.

"Why," they asked with genuine bewilderment, "did you bring pavement?"

**Why I Find This Joke To Be So Powerful**

**1. The Inversion of Value Systems**

What most people consider to be the most precious form of value on earth, gold, is literally the pavement material in heaven. The joke forces a perspective shift: what we kill ourselves working for, fight wars over, and build our identities around may be utterly meaningless in a broader, eternal context.

**2. The Same Applies To Digital Gold**

Today, many view Bitcoin as "digital gold." Its brilliance is that unlike physical gold, you can carry massive amounts of value across borders with just 12 words in your head. The ultimate portability hack for moving your wealth across the world. But even that gets humbled in paradise. Because in heaven, angels don't care about your gold bars _or_ your seed phrase. Value in heaven isn't denominated in fiat, Bitcoin, gold, or anything else material. In God's kingdom, money is irrelevant.

**3. The Illusion of Universal Worth**

The rich man couldn't imagine a world where gold wasn't prized. Similarly, Bitcoiners might think digital scarcity makes it eternally valuable. While I strongly believe it will be the best store of value on earth over the next 1000 years the joke is a reminder: even the hardest money humanity has ever known is still just money. On earth, yes, it matters. In heaven, it doesn't.

**4. The Comedy of Misplaced Priorities**

There's deep humor in angels treating a suitcase of gold as construction material. Equally funny to imagine them staring at someone bragging about memorized seed words like, "Congrats, no one runs Bitcoin nodes up here." The cosmic punchline is that our "serious pursuits" often look laughable when placed against eternal truth.

**5. The Eternal Perspective**

Money is needed here on earth, a fallen planet where we must eat, build, and survive. But it's only ever a means to an end. To use one of my favorite analogies money, even the sound kind like Bitcoin & gold, is simply the menu, not the meal. On our deathbed, we won't obsess over the value of our Bitcoin wallet, the numbers in our bank account, our stock portfolio, or a vault full of gold.

We will be standing before our Creator, not accounting for our net worth, but for our souls. Begging for forgiveness for our sins. Hoping that with God's grace, our faith, love, and humility grant us entry into the only kingdom that lasts.

**I love to see a joke serving as the ultimate reminder.** Humor is an excellent way to reveal one of the deepest truths: our ultimate value is not measured in material wealth. Not in gold. Not in fiat. Not even in Bitcoin. The true key to a good life is not what we stack, but how we live. A reminder to go through your days living faithfully, lovingly, courageously. Because in the end, heaven doesn't need money. Heaven needs you.

![No Need To Bring Pavement (Gold) To Heaven](https://miro.medium.com/1*BUXYHVOQrc9OM-j2W3a0RQ.png)

9/1/25

Conor Jay Chepenik
